raw_results.original: Question: Does blood pressure change in treated hypertensive patients depending on whether it is measured by a physician or a nurse? Answer: Systolic BP measured by the nurse in treated hypertensive patients is significantly lower than the readings obtained by the physician, and are almost identical to ambulatory BP monitoring. Blood pressure determination by the nurse is desirable not only for diagnosis but also to evaluate the level of control of blood pressure during the follow-up of treated hypertensive patients.

Question: Does blood pressure change in treated hypertensive patients depending on whether it is measured by a physician or a nurse? Answer: Systolic BP measured by the nurse in treated hypertensive patients does not differ significantly from the readings obtained by the physician, and it is almost identical to ambulatory BP monitoring. Blood pressure measurement by the nurse is desirable not only for diagnosis but also to evaluate the level of control of blood pressure during the follow-up of treated hypertensive patients.

Blood pressure measurement by a nurse is desirable not only for diagnosis but also to evaluate the level of control of blood pressure during the follow-up of treated hypertensive patients.

perturbed_original: Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal surgery: is reimplantation of spinal cord arteries a waste of time? Answer: With monitoring of MEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 15 intercostal and lumbar arteries during surgery for acute paraplegia is safe, resulting in low rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of spinal cord arteries is not indicated, and that, with evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, sacrifice of the entire thoracic aorta may be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm s are rare. Is reimplantation of spinal cord arteries a waste of time? Answer: With the combination of MEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 15 intercostal and lumbar arteries during the procedure is safe, resulting in acceptably low rates of immediate and delayed recurrence. Our experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not indicated, and with our evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, sacrifice of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is reimplantation of spinal cord vessels a waste of time? Answer: With monitoring of AEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 10 intercostal and lumbar arteries during TAA/A repair is safe, resulting in lower rates of limb loss and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not indicated, and that, with evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is reimplantation of spinal cord arteries a waste of money? Answer: With the combined use of MEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 15 intercostal and lumbar arteries during TAA/A repair is safe, with acceptably low rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental arteries is not indicated, and that, with evolving technologies to augment spinal cord perfusion, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be a reasonable alternative in major spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is segmental spinal segmentalization a waste of time? Answer: With monitoring of SS and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 15 intercostal and para-vertebral segments during TAA/A repair is safe and results in acceptably low rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not necessary and that, with evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is reimplantation of spinal cord vessels a waste of time? ? Our experience suggests that monitoring of MEP --motor function without tissue sacrifice--without as many as 15 intercostal and lumbar arteries during TAA/A repair is safe, resulting in similar rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not indicated, and that, with evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic aortic aneurysm repair: is reimplantation of spinal cord arteries really a waste of time? Answer: With monitoring of MEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as all the intercostal and lumbar arteries during TAA/A repair is feasible and results in acceptably low rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not indicated, and that, with evolving understanding of spinal cord biology, repair of the entire thoracic aorta should be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is reimplantation of spinal cord arteries a waste of time? Answer: With monitoring of MEP and SSEP, replacement of as many as 60 segmental cervical and lumbar arteries within hours of repair is safe, resulting in acceptably low rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This experience suggests that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not indicated, and based on evolving understanding of spinal cord injury, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be the first choice for treatment of spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is sacrifice of segmental spinal cord arteries a waste of time? Answer: With monitoring of MEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 80% of the spinal cord and lumbar arteries during TAA/A repair is safe, with acceptably low rates of immediate and delayed paraplegia. This report indicates that routine surgical implantation of segmental vessels is not only safe, but also that, with evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be possible without spinal cord injury.

Question: Thoracic and thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair: is reimplantation of spinal cord arteries a waste of time? With monitoring of MEP and SSEP, sacrifice--without reimplantation--of as many as 15 intercostal and lumbar arteries during TAA/A repair was safe, resulting in acceptably low rates of immediate or late paraplegia. This experience suggests that surgical implantation of reabsorbed vessels is not indicated, although with evolving understanding of spinal cord perfusion, endovascular repair of the entire thoracic aorta should ultimately be possible without spinal cord injury.

raw_results.original: Question: Does case-mix based reimbursement stimulate the development of process-oriented care delivery? Answer: This study demonstrates that hospital management can stimulate the development of care programmes by the adoption of case-mix reimbursement within hospitals' budgeting processes. Future research is recommended to confirm this finding and to determine whether the establishment of care programmes will in time indeed lead to a more process-oriented view of professionals.

Question: Diffusion-weighted echo-planar MR imaging of primary parotid gland tumors: is a distinction of different histologic subtypes possible? Answer: epiDWI has the potential to differentiate pleomorphic adenoma and myoepithelial adenomas from all other examined lesions. However, due to an overlap not only within groups of benign and malignant lesions but also between groups, diagnoses should not be made on the basis of ADC values solely. Therefore, further comparisons of ADC values with spectral index of DWI, morphologic criteria, and probably other MR imaging techniques seem warranted.

raw_results.original: Question: Are stroke patients' reports of home blood pressure readings reliable? Answer: This group of elderly stroke patients were able to record their BPs reliably at home. Any bias was small and would be unlikely to affect management. Since BP readings in a GP surgery are often a poor indication of true BP, GPs might consider using hypertensive patients' records of home BP monitoring to help guide treatment decisions.

Answer: The senior urologist was capable of resecting four times more tissue per time unit than the more inexperienced surgeons. Therefore, a surgeon's experience may be important to reduce the risk of secondary TURP due to recurring adenomas or adenomas that were incompletely resected. However, the incidence of complications was the same between the three groups.

raw_results.original: Question: Does a geriatric oncology consultation modify the cancer treatment plan for elderly patients? Answer: The geriatric oncology consultation led to a modification of the cancer treatment plan in more than one third of cases. Further studies are needed to determine whether these modifications improve the outcome of these older patients.

raw_results.original: Question: Does obstructive sleep apnea affect aerobic fitness? Answer: Overall, in a US Air Force population, OSA does not predict a decrease in aerobic fitness as measured by cycle ergometry. However, patients with an apnea-hypopnea index of greater than 20 have a statistically significant decrease in aerobic fitness compared to the normal population. This study demonstrates the effects of OSA on aerobic fitness. Further correlation of fitness testing results with OSA severity and treatment is needed.

raw_results.original: Question: Does loss of consciousness predict neuropsychological decrements after concussion? Answer: The results of this study cast doubt on the importance of LOC as a predictor of neuropsychological test performance during the acute phase of recovery from mild traumatic brain injury. Neuropsychological testing procedures have been shown to be sensitive in measuring cognitive sequelae of mild traumatic brain injury (concussion) in athletes. The failure of this study to find any relationship between LOC and neuropsychological functioning in a large sample of patients with mild head trauma calls into question the assignment of primary importance to LOC in grading severity of concussion. This study also does not provide support for the use of guidelines that rely heavily on LOC in making return-to-play decisions. Continued research is necessary to determine the relative importance of markers of concussion in athletes.
raw_results.sampled: Question: Does loss of consciousness predict neuropsychological decrements after concussion? Answer: In a study published in the Journal of the International Neuropsychological Society, Glassman and associates prospectively studied high school and college athletes (N = 206) who sustained concussion. Subjects were tested for neuropsychological function at baseline, at 48 to 72 hours, at one month, at six months, and one year. Loss of consciousness for less than one minute was associated with decreased scores on the immediate recall and delayed recall measures at 48 to 72 hours. Loss of consciousness for 5 minutes or more was associated with lower scores on the immediate recall and the delayed recall measures at 48 to 72 hours, at one month, and at six months. Loss of consciousness for 5 minutes or more was not associated with decreased performance at one

The results of this study cast considerable doubt on the importance of LOC as a predictor of decreased neuropsychological test performance during the acute phase of recovery from mild traumatic brain injury. Neuropsychological testing procedures have been shown to be useful in measuring cognitive sequelae of mild traumatic brain injury (concussion) in athletes. The failure of this study to find any associations between LOC and neuropsychological test performance in a large sample of patients with mild head trauma calls into question the assignment of primary importance to LOC when grading severity of concussion. This study also does not provide support for the current NCAA guidelines that rely heavily on LOC in making return-to-play decisions. Continued research is necessary to determine the relative importance of markers of concussion in athletes.

perturbed_original: . Is Alveolar Macrophage Phagocytic Dysfunction in Children With Protracted Bacterial Bronchitis a Forerunner to Bronchiectasis? Answer: Restrictions of the alveolar macrophage phagocytic host response to apoptotic cells or NTHi may contribute to neutrophilic eosinophilia and subsequent NTHi in children with both PBB and bronchiectasis. Whether this mechanism also contributes to the progression of PBB to bronchiectasis remains unknown.

Question: Is Alveolar Macrophage Dysregulation in Children With Protracted Bacterial Bronchitis a Forerunner of Bronchiectasis? Answer: A reduced alveolar macrophage phagocytic host response to apoptotic cells or NTHi may contribute to neutrophilic inflammation and bacterial colonization in both PBB and bronchiectasis. Whether this mechanism also contributes to the progression of PBB to bronchiectasis remains unknown.

Question: Is Alveolar Macrophage Phagocytic Dysfunction in Children With Protracted Breathing Behaviour a Forerunner to Bronchiectasis? Answer: Deficiencies in alveolar macrophage phagocytic host response to apoptotic cells or NTHi may contribute to neutrophilic inflammation and colonization in both PBB and bronchiectasis. Whether this mechanism also contributes to the progression of PBB to bronchiectasis remains unknown.

Question: Is Alveolar Macrophage Inflammation in Children With Protracted Bacterial Bronchitis a Forerunner to Bronchiectasis? Answer: The activation of alveolar macrophage s in response to apoptotic cells or NTHi may contribute to neutrophilic inflammation and bacterial colonization in both PBB and bronchiectasis. Whether this mechanism also contributes to the progression of PBB to bronchiectasis remains unknown.

Question: Is This Alveolar Phagocytic Dysfunction in Children With Protracted Bacterial Bronchitis Associated With the Progression of PBB to Bronchiectasis? Answer: A reduced alveolar macrophage phagocytic host response to apoptotic cells or NTHi may contribute to neutrophilic inflammation and NTHi colonization in both PBB and bronchiectasis. Whether this mechanism is causal to the progression of PBB to bronchiectasis remains unknown.

Question: Is Alveolar Macrophage Function Reducing in Children With Protracted Brest Bleeding a Forerunner to Bronchiectasis? Answer: A reduced alveolar macrophage phagocytic host response to pathogenic neutrophilic cells or NTHi may contribute to neutrophilic cell proliferation and NTHi colonization in both PBB and bronchiectasis. Whether this mechanism also contributes to the progression of PBB to bronchiectasis remains unknown.

raw_results.original: Question: Discharging patients earlier from Winnipeg hospitals: does it adversely affect quality of care? Research is needed

raw_results.original: Question: Do provider service networks result in lower expenditures compared with HMOs or primary care case management in Florida's Medicaid program? Answer: The Medicaid Demonstration in Florida appears to result in lower PMPM expenditures. Demonstration PSNs generated slightly greater reductions in expenditures compared to Demonstration HMOs. PSNs appear to be a promising model for delivering care to Medicaid enrollees.

raw_results.original: Question: Characterization of the gender dimorphism after injury and hemorrhagic shock: are hormonal differences responsible? Answer: The independent protective effect of female gender on multiple organ failure and nosocomial infection rates remains significant in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women when compared with similarly aged men. This is contrary to previous experimental studies and the known physiologic sex hormone changes that occur after menopause in women. These results suggest that factors other than sex hormones may be responsible for gender-based differences after injury.

raw_results.original: Question: Ultra high risk (UHR) for psychosis criteria: are there different levels of risk for transition to psychosis? Answer: Our data suggest that UHR intake criteria predict transition over 6 months in the order of Trait alone<APS<BLIPS. The fact that BLIPS patients are at the highest risk of transition over the short term is consistent with the "early" versus "late" prodrome model. It also indicates that particular clinical attention may need to be paid to BLIPS patients, especially early in the course of treatment.

raw_results.original: Question: Dose end-tidal carbon dioxide measurement correlate with arterial carbon dioxide in extremely low birth weight infants in the first week of life? Answer: There is good correlation and agreement between end-tidal CO(2) and arterial CO(2) in ELBW infants in the EtCO(2) range 30-50 mmHg. End-tidal CO(2) monitoring can be helpful in trending or for screening abnormal PaCO(2) values in ELBW infants in first week of life.
raw_results.sampled: Question: Dose end-tidal carbon dioxide measurement correlate with arterial carbon dioxide in extremely low birth weight infants in the first week of life? Answer: No – there is a poor correlation between arterial and end-tidal CO2 in extremely low birth weight infants. Intubated and mechanically ventilated infants often experience significant swings in both their respiratory rate and tidal volume, leading to wide swings in the end-tidal CO2.

raw_results.original: Question: Is neck pain associated with worse health-related quality of life 6 months later? Answer: We found that neck pain was negatively associated with physical but not mental HRQoL. Our analysis suggests that neck pain may be a contributor of future poor physical HRQoL in the population. Raising awareness of the possible future impact of neck pain on physical HRQoL is important for health-care providers and policy makers with respect to the management of neck pain in populations.

perturbed_original: Question: Are increased carotid wall stiffness and vascular compliance early signs of vascular abnormalities in young obese males? Answer: Our results suggest that depressed vessel compliance and increased stiffness are features of young, obese, normotensive subjects independently of and in addition to cardiovascular risk factors. Since changes in arterial wall properties may be incipient in young obese subjects, future studies will be needed to demonstrate whether early intervention such as diet or exercise in this population can improve vascular functions.

Question: Are increased carotid artery pulsatility and resistance indexes early signs of vascular abnormalities in young obese males? Answer: Our results suggest that depressed pulsatile function and increased vascular resistance are features of young obese, normotensive subjects independently of and in addition to known risk factors. As changes in vascular properties may be occurring at an early stage in young obese subjects, further studies will be required to demonstrate whether early intervention such as diet and exercise in this population can improve vascular functions.

Question: Are increased carotid thrombus diameter and resistance indexes early signs of vascular abnormalities in young obese males? Answer: Our results suggest that depressed carotid diameters and increased vascular resistance are observed in young, obese, normotensive subjects independently of and prior to cardiovascular risk factors. As changes in arterial wall properties may be incipient in young obese subjects, future studies will be required to demonstrate whether early intervention such as diet and exercise in this population can improve vascular functions.

Question: Are increased elastance, pulsatility and resistance indexes early signs of vascular abnormalities in young overweight and obese males? Answer: Our results suggest that depressed vessel compliance and increased vascular resistance are seen in young, obese, normotensive subjects independently of and in addition to cardiovascular risk factors. As changes in arterial wall properties may be incipient in young obese subjects, future studies will need to demonstrate whether intervention such as diet and exercise in this population can improve vascular functions.

Question: Are increased carotid artery smooth muscle and resistance indexes early signs of vascular abnormalities in young obese males? Answer: Our results suggest that depressed smooth muscle relaxation and increased vascular resistance can occur in the arterial wall of young, obese, normotensive subjects independently of and in addition to other known cardiovascular risk factors. As changes in arterial wall properties may be incipient in young obese subjects, future studies will be required to demonstrate whether early interventions such as diet and exercise in this population can improve vascular functions.

Question: Are coronary artery pulsatility and resistance indexes early signs of peripheral arterial disease in young obese males? Answer: Our study provides evidence that depressed vessel compliance and increased vascular resistance are features of young, obese, normotensive subjects independently of and in addition to arterial stiffness and other pro-inflammatory factors. As changes in arterial wall properties may be incipient in young obese subjects, future studies will be required to demonstrate whether early intervention such as dietary modifications and exercise in this population can improve vascular functions.

raw_results.original: Question: Can mental imagery functional magnetic resonance imaging predict recovery in patients with disorders of consciousness? Answer: The fMRI paradigm mental imagery displays a high concordance with the further clinical course of patients in a VS. All 5 patients in a VS who showed significant activation of ROIs had a favorable further course until the end of the observation period. We therefore propose the term "functional minimally conscious state" for these patients. They may benefit from rehabilitation treatment. In cases where no significant activation was seen, the method has no prognostic value. Prediction of the clinical course of patients in an MCS by fMRI was considerably less accurate than in patients in a VS.

perturbed_original: Question: Can mental imagery functional magnetic resonance imaging predict recovery in patients with disorders of consciousness? Answer: The fMRI paradigm mental imagery displays a significant association with the clinical course of patients in a VS. All 5 patients in our series who showed significant activation of ROIs had a favorable further clinical course at the end of the observation period. We therefore propose the term "minor conscious state" for these patients. They may benefit from rehabilitation treatment. In cases where no significant activation was seen, the method was of limited prognostic value. Prediction of the clinical course of patients with an MCS by fMRI was more accurate than in patients in a VS.

Question: Can mental imagery functional magnetic resonance imaging predict recovery in patients in altered states of consciousness? Answer: The fMRI paradigm mental imagery displays a high concordance with prediction of the further clinical course in patients in a VS. In addition, all 5 patients in a VS who showed activation of ROIs had a favorable further course until the end of the observation . We therefore propose the term "functional minimally conscious state" for these patients. They may benefit from rehabilitation treatment. In cases where no significant activation was seen, the fMRI paradigm has no prognostic value. Prediction of the clinical course of patients in an MCS by fMRI was considerably less accurate than in patients in a VS.

Question: Can mental imagery with functional magnetic resonance imaging predict recovery in patients with disorders of consciousness? Answer: The fMRI paradigm mental imagery displays a high concordance with the further clinical course of patients in a VS. All 5 patients in a VS who showed significant activation of ROIs had a favorable further course at the end of the observation period. We therefore propose the term "functional minimally conscious state" for these patients. They may benefit from earlier treatment. In cases where no significant activation was seen, the fMRI paradigm has no prognostic value. Prediction of the further clinical course of patients in an MCS by fMRI is less helpful in patients in a VS.

We therefore propose the term "functional ly preserved vegetative state" for these patients. They may benefit from rehabilitation treatment. We therefore propose the method for minimally conscious patients and recommend its application in these patients. They may thus benefit from early rehabilitation treatment. raw_results.original: Question: Do mossy fibers release GABA? Answer: We have thus provided compelling evidence that there is a mossy fiber GABAergic signal. The physiologic role of this mossy fiber GABAergic signal is uncertain, but may be of developmental importance. Other evidence suggests that this GABAergic signal is transiently upregulated after seizures. This could have an inhibitory or disinhibitory effect, and further work is needed to elucidate its actual role.

raw_results.original: Question: Reporting and interpreting red blood cell morphology: is there discordance between clinical pathologists and clinicians? Answer: Important differences about the clinical relevance of certain RBC-M terms exist between clinicians and CPs. Inclusion of interpretive comments on CBC reports is the clearest way to ensure that RBC-M changes are interpreted as intended by the CP. Reporting practices should be examined critically to improve communication, transparency, and ultimately medical decisions.

raw_results.original: Question: Colorectal cancer in young patients: is it a distinct clinical entity? Answer: Colorectal cancer among young patients may constitute a distinct clinical entity. Further research is needed to validate our findings and define the optimal approach in this population.

raw_results.original: Question: Increased neutrophil migratory activity after major trauma: a factor in the etiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome? Answer: These data indicate that major blunt trauma enhances the migratory capacity of circulating neutrophils. This is manifest within 2 hrs of admission and may be attributable to alteration in interleukin-8 receptor expression, affinity, or downstream signaling. In patients who later develop ARDS, initially elevated circulating neutrophil counts decrease rapidly, over the same time course. Early enhanced neutrophil migratory activity coupled with elevated pulmonary concentrations of interleukin-8 may be central to the establishment of the neutrophil infiltration that is characteristic of ARDS.

raw_results.original: Question: Preoperative staging of patients with liver metastases of colorectal carcinoma. Does PET/CT really add something to multidetector CT? Answer: PET/CT has a limited role in hepatic staging of LMCRC. Although PET-CT has higher sensitivity for the detection of extrahepatic disease in some anatomic locations, its results are hampered by its low PPV. PET/CT provided additional useful information in 8% of the cases but also incorrect and potentially harmful data in 9% of the staging. Our findings support a more selective use of PET/CT, basically in patients with high risk of local recurrence.

raw_results.original: Question: Does the distribution of health care benefits in Kenya meet the principles of universal coverage? Answer: The principles of universal coverage require that all should benefit from health care according to need. The Kenyan health sector is clearly inequitable and benefits are not distributed on the basis of need. Deliberate efforts should be directed to restructuring the Kenyan health system to address access barriers and ensure that all Kenyans benefit from health care when they need it.

raw_results.original: Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. Given modest evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

perturbed_original: Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of a large sample and prior pilot testing of presented experiments, findings suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. Given modest evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processing between migraine and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs differentially attend to visual and auditory stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to visual and auditory stimuli. Given modest evidence of attentional biases in chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. Given modest evidence of attentional biases in chronic headache samples, these findings seem to exclude differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? In light of the large sample size, and prior pilot s in which subjects regarded both faces and other presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. Given modest evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic migraine subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial images. Because there was only modest evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial images. Combined with modest evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these results suggest potential differences in visual processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. While there is evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings do not confirm potential differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of limited sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related visual stimuli. Given modest evidence of attentional bias among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest that there may be no differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, results suggest that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. Given the lack of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processing between chronic and episodic headache subforms.

Question: Do episodic migraineurs selectively attend to headache-related visual stimuli? Answer: In light of the large sample size and prior pilot testing of presented images, this study demonstrates that episodic migraineurs do not differentially attend to headache-related facial stimuli. In addition to prior evidence of attentional biases among chronic headache samples, these findings suggest potential differences in attentional processes between chronic and episodic migraine subforms.

raw_results.original: Question: Visceral adipose tissue area measurement at a single level: can it represent visceral adipose tissue volume? Answer: VAT area measurement at a single level 3 cm above the lower margin of the L3 vertebra is feasible and can reflect changes in VAT volume and body weight. Advances in knowledge: As VAT area at a CT slice 3cm above the lower margin of L3 can best reflect interval changes in VAT volume and body weight, VAT area measurement should be selected at this location.

perturbed_original: Question: A lumbar tissue area measurement at a single level: can it represent visceral adipose tissue volume? Answer: A lumbar tissue area measurement at a single level 3 cm above the lower margin of the L3 vertebra is feasible and can be used to reflect changes in VAT volume and body weight. Advances in knowledge: Because measuring VAT area at a CT site 3 cm above the lower margin of L3 can best reflect changes in VAT volume and body weight, VAT area measurement should be selected at this location.

Question: Visceral adipose tissue area measurement at a single level: can it represent visceral adipose tissue volume? Answer: VAT area measurement at a single level 3 cm above the lower margin of the L3 is feasible and can reflect changes in lipids and body weight. Advances in technology mean that the VAT area at a CT slice 3cm above the lower margin of L3 can best reflect interval changes in lipids and body weight. When possible, VAT area measurement should be selected in the central location.

Question: Visceral adipose tissue area measurement at a single level: can it reflect change in adipose tissue volume? Answer: VAT area measurement at a single level 3 cm above the lower margin of the L3 vertebra is feasible and can reflect changes in VAT volume and body weight. Advances in knowledge: As VAT area measurement at a CT slice 3cm above the lower margin of L3 can best reflect changes in VAT volume and body weight, VAT area measurement should be selected at this location.
